videos.title: Is ‚Çπ84 Lakh In America Poor??? | Purchasing Power Parity ExplainedVarun-‚ÄùIt‚Äôs recording right?‚Äù
videos.transcript: Time: 00:10 - 00:20 So it all started when a tweet went viral recently about India v/sAmerica price parity. A lot of people were saying that, you know, getting a 30 lakh salary in India Time: 00:20 - 00:30 is equivalent to getting $120k, which is roughly about a crore in America. Another person posted this. People who were living in America got angry Time: 00:30 - 00:40 and were like, you cannot put a price on fresh air. Honestly, it's been a decade long heated debate and I started questioning, are these figures true? Time: 00:40 - 00:50 How much does it actually cost to live in America? How much really is $100k worth in the US? How much is that worth in India? Is it ‚Çπ30 lakhs? Is it ‚Çπ40 lakhs? Or is it ‚Çπ80 lakhs? Time: 00:50 - 01:00 What would the equivalent lifestyle be? So to get an accurate answer. I decided to make a video. I traveled to the top American cities last month Time: 01:00 - 01:10 and found the answer myself. In this video, I've created comparisons that provide the one video you need to answer your questions about price parity in America. With examples by the way. I went there. Time: 01:10 - 01:20 I am a testament to this. And I'll also show you what America, San Francisco, New York was like. Let's begin. Time: 01:20 - 01:30 We start with the basics first. Let me explain something called Purchasing Power Parity. So Purchasing Power Parity or ‚ÄúPPP‚Äù is simply the ratio of the price of a basket of goods at one location, divided Time: 01:30 - 01:40 by the price of the basket of goods at a different location. But why is it important? You see, prices of goods and services differ between countries, Time: 01:40 - 01:50 and it can be difficult to compare how much your money will buy in different places. Let me give you an example. $3 can get you one can of soda in America, but three cans in India. Time: 01:50 - 02:00 And this is where ‚ÄúPPP‚Äù or Purchasing Power Parity comes in. It basically lets us compare the real value of money between different countries, and also helps us adjust GDP to show how an economy is doing. Time: 02:00 - 02:10 Now, you know, every time it comes to this U.S. versus India comparison, people will say that PPP is too simplistic. It doesn't take into account a lot of things, Time: 02:10 - 02:20 which is also a fair argument, because your basket of goods or spending habits may not be similar to other person's basket of goods. For example, if you're a fresher, your needs would be very different Time: 02:20 - 02:30 from a family of four who will probably need car, schooling for their children, etc. Based on the current calculation, though the OECD says that $100k is ‚Çπ23 lakhs in India. Time: 02:30 - 02:40 The world Bank says it's ‚Çπ21 lakhs. But if you stick with me till the end, I'll tell you what I learned from my experience. So from the very moment I stepped in American soil, Time: 02:40 - 02:50 I started doing my research. The very first person we met was a driver sent by Google, who came to pick us up in San Francisco. Time: 02:50 - 03:00 He was from Brazil, had moved to America to work, and he was just the right candidate because guess what? He was making $100,000 a year. Time: 03:00 - 03:10 Yes. Let that sink in. A driver making $100,000. That's basically 84 lakhs. Honestly, I thought he was lying. But over ten days, I asked, ‚ÄúHow much do you make?‚Äù to every single driver, Time: 03:10 - 03:20 every person I met across San Francisco, L.A., New York. And all the drivers we met were making 7-8 thousand dollars per month. Time: 03:20 - 03:30 Yep! It blew my mind too. It also made me question, does everybody starting out in America make like $100,000? Is it more like making Time: 03:30 - 03:40 5 LPA salary in India? Because drivers back home make that much? Also, does it mean that all our friends in US getting a one crore package are actually just making entry level salaries? Time: 03:40 - 03:50 So it's obviously a little more nuanced than that. But before we talk about that, I want to quickly thank our partner for this video, Odoo. Odoo is an enterprise resource management planning software, which you can use to manage Time: 03:50 - 04:00 all your business needs like sales, accounting and CRM. Now, if you are looking to streamline your operations and stay on top of the tasks, Odoo‚Äôs open Source project management Time: 04:00 - 04:10 tool is just what you need. You can organize your task using different views like. Visualize your workflow with Kanban, that shows all the tasks as cards with main info at front. Or get a bird's eye view of your project timeline Time: 04:10 - 04:20 with Gantt chart to spot potential roadblock and spot key metrics, or a list view to simplify or make batch changes. You can easily schedule activities, Time: 04:20 - 04:30 add all the info as log notes, see the emails and conversations with clients or team at the chatter, put hours worked in the timesheet, and much more. And you know the best part? All of this is for free Time: 04:30 - 04:40 since Odoo‚Äôs first app is free for life with unlimited support and hosting. So check out Odoo from the link in description below. Now back to the video. Time: 04:40 - 04:50 This was my very first candidate, so I was also a little apprehensive of recording him because I didn't want him to get angry. But I also casually asked him, so how do you spend your $100,000? Time: 04:50 - 05:00 That's a lot of money, you must be saving a lot, right? He was like, ‚ÄúNo, $100,000 is nothing in San Francisco, you know‚Äù ‚ÄúI live an hour north of San Francisco and I pay like, $3,000 rent.‚Äù Time: 05:00 - 05:10 ‚ÄúI've got a kid, so it's kind of tough.‚Äù This specific day will be a rent of $3,000. Living an hour away north of San Francisco. Time: 05:10 - 05:20 $3,000 is ‚Çπ2.5 lakhs. comments.timestamp: My hypothesis is that Indians go the America for one of 3 reasons:

comments.text:
1. To save money
2. To escape family
3. To escape society
If you don't have one of these 3 problems, India is likely the better choice in
the long term. But people who want to stay a short term in the US would end
up making a much bigger corpus than they can ever in India. The PPP
argument applies to only those planning to live in the US.

comments.timestamp: American Indian, living in the U.S. for 24 years now. Here's my perspective -

comments.text:
a LOT of things have changed since the U.S. boom period of ex-President
Bill Clinton. That era was the absolute best time to move to the U.S.
Homelessness was always a part of the U.S., but if you knew how to read a
JAVA book, you had a job in the mid to late 90s. I personally know
Veterinarian docs who shifted to IT during those days and made a killing.
Today's U.S. is entirely different - highly competitive, technology changing
every week (if not sooner) and a huge pool of talent available. Combine that
with a rising inflation, geo-political dynamics, and you get the U.S. of today.
It still is (by many standards) one of the best countries to live in, but it's
definitely not the U.S. of the golden era. This is fact.

making an opinion, talk to someone who is actually living in the US.
